posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Be seriously wary of anything built in the last two decades if it's in a neighborhood where everything was done by a single builder. In every example I've seen, they cheaped their way through every house in terms of both labor and materials. In some cases they skimped out on necessary things like proper flashing at roof edges which will inevitably lead to super expensive repairs. Not that builders in the past were any better, but the problems have had time to come to light.

Keep an eye out of work done by previous homeowners. Some people think they can /diy/ major structural changes without having a clue. I looked at a place where some numbnuts had removed a load bearing column to open up a living room, and there were cracks on adjacent walls where the place was starting to cave.

Inspectors are sort of a necessary evil. Some are bullshit, but I was saved from a money pit by one once so they have their place. Get your own and not one associated with your lender or realtor. General inspectors won't check certain systems in depth, so if you look at a property with anything like EIFS stucco, septic, or well water get a separate inspection for those.

Use Google street view to get an idea of what an area looks like if you don't already know. If you see derelicts or trash everywhere, don't waste your time looking at the house.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You are going to get a lot of contradictory information. For example, the thing about trees. changes in water, vegitation near your foundation - they all fuck things up. But not too much you can do about it. First time home buyer. been here 10 years now, and I'll tell you where our surprises were.

-Got a separate inspector for the AC. He found a significant issue - there was a 5 ton unit, but the house was ducted for a 4 ton. It was overworking the unit. Luckily the unit lasted another 7 years, but it was a good bargaining point. When we put in new unit had to pay an extra $300 for some duct changes.

-visit house at night on a weekend. Just chill in your car for an hour or more. It seems creepy, but you are gonna be sleeping there for the next 10 years. Did you know kids drag race on the access road? That you can hear the traffic from the freeway quite clearly at night?

-don't buy nicest house on your block. We fell for this. it didn't start that way, but as we fixed up the house, landscape, etc... you realize that there are some shitty houses around, epecially rentals, leave trash out blah blah blah. These places bring down your value and you can't do shit about it. funfact: last year with housing prices going crazy, 2 of the 10 houses on our cul de sac, including the one next to ours, were sold to out of town AirBnB faggots. Constant groups of strangers as neighbors now. I fucking hate it. They won't even repair the fence between us that has rotted apart, and won't split costs with us to do it.

-House is "just settling". look at foundations of other houses around you... are they all cracked? knock on some doors and say you are interested in moving in - have they had to do any foundation repair? Turns out everyone on our cul-de-sac has, because of the type of soil we have. That was $15,000 I wasn't expecting!

cont

>>2543909
Some disappointing updates which is why I didn't post them. I figured nobody else cared and I'm not sure if I'll be able to finish the project before the thread loses momentum. I brought the wheel out to test in the car and when attaching it up to my intended power source the car triggers the horn. I have an electrical diagnostic manual for my car so I referenced the horn circuit and it turns out it powers the horn when the circuit is closed (kind of obvious in hindsight). The doubly disappointing news is my other constant 12v power, which runs to the cruise control buttons, also triggers the horn when grounded because it shares the same inputs. I asked an electrical engineering friend if there was any way around it with the current layout and the only thing he could come up with was borrowing a signal wire from the cruise control circuit and redirecting it through a raspberry pi. From there I considered tearing down my clockspring and replacing the ribbon inside with one that contains more wires. I was wondering about amperage as well, so I googled how much amperage a clockspring could handle and happened upon this thread from someone asking the same question for the same application as mine: http://www.saturnfans.com/forums/showthread.php?t=267981

In any case, my plan now is to salvage the clockspring from a newer car with more leads as well as from another identical Honda as mine and frankenstein the two together. Probably going to take a trip to a scrap yard sometime this week.
>inb4 but muh splicing airbag wires
suck my dick I'm going to have warm hands if it kills me

To make all matters worse, my DC power supply came in DOA. didn't output any power unless I beat it, then it spiked and slowly dropped voltage from like 15 to 0. I did power the wheel via a car battery to confirm it works, however, and I'm pretty happy with my layout (although I'd put the wires further apart/more on the inside if I did it again)

I took the day off work to get some stuff done and used the opportunity to stop by a nearby junkyard and pick up a donor clockspring. This came out of a mid-2000s Acura TL with a bunch of buttons on the wheel. after breaking it apart and counting the copper stripes on the ribbon cable, I found 8 independent leads on each of the two internal cables (16 total), half of which seem like thicker, high voltage lines with the other half being thinner signal wires. Depending on how I decide to assemble this, I might not even need the second cable and I would still have one extra power source for any other buttons I'd want to add in the future. Try as I might, I've not been able to find an affordable clockspring from the same year of my actual car, so I might have to do some excessive afro-engineering and chop up a spare, older model spring I have and solder on the leads from the newer model spring once I know it's all assembled properly. Basic framing, especially for non-living spaces, isn't *too* hard but there are things that will catch you up. Revit is particularly good for this because it's designed for designing buildings, and will catch that kind of framing mistake for you in a lot of cases.

Don't go in blind. Building codes arent just a meme, they're written in blood, and you should learn from those who came before you by adhering to them. That said, following building codes isn't enough to get you a "good" structure. That's quite a bit more involved.

I think OP, assuming they have basic competency, can build a bog-standard garage with a bit of research and time. I don't expect it to win any civil engineering awards, but if you're not stupid, follow building codes, do your research, and don't cheap out on materials, you should be alright.

>>2544826
I have been using sketchup pro to model the tinyhouse I am currently building. It's about as simple a 3d modeling program can get. You just create generic assets, like 2x4x8s and sheets of plywood, and copy/paste them as needed. I use the Pro version on a 30 day trail using accounts made with a throwaway email in order to have access to the 3d model and plug in warehouse which provides a lot of pre-made assets 1 click away, like pre-made water totes, vehicles, antennas, etc. I also used a number if plug-ins during the design such as a sun-orientation-adjuster so I can visualize how the sun will come in through the windows at different times of year as well ad a center-of-gravity plug in where I can give different materials different weights by volume to determine how heavy and balanced the structure is (important for a house on wheels).

Important! If you use sketchpad you need to be a organization nazi with the tagging system. Every asset you make will need a tag and if you duplicate an item it's tag moves with it. So if you want to show/hide parts of your structure you need to make sure the seperate sections do not overlap I'm tags.

Wood boards that make up the framing should be tagged "framing walls" the foundation tagged "foundation" the roof framing "framing roof" etc. Then you csn show/hide each section as you want. BUT if you create a 2x4x8 and tag it "framing walls" then copy/paste it and use it for the roof, your tags will not show/hide correctly. You will have to go back to every copy/pasted instance of the asset used in the roof and re-tag it. Also grouping assets or turning them into components applies an additional tag on top of the original assets that needs to be managed too. So if you have studs tagged "framing walls" and you group all the south facing together and give it the tag "framing walls south" you will now need BOTH tags visible to see that wall. I'm sure there's some guides on this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2548029
Lots of spelling mistakes because of mobile sorry. It's also important that you create assets to exact sizes if you want to use the model as a blueprint. A sheet of 1/2" plywood is not 1/2" thick for example. And you shouldn't butt sheets of plywood directly up to eachother, 1/8" between them is recommended for expansion. Also when you scale an object, you can type in exact numerical values rather than eyeballing it.

Not a big deal for roughing out an idea, but important if you want a blueprint you can follow to exactly later on.

>>2548069
Shear walls serve the function of wall bracing vastly better than traditional methods. The exterior sheathing on my house is fastened on the smallest OC recommendations for maximum bracing and was assembled with wood glue as an additional layer of reinforcement. The interior walls will also be glued+screwed plywood for even more stiffness.

Every trailer and rv frame used to be assembled by this exact same method, but often with thinner plywood, fewer fasteners, and only 2x2 framing in an effort to save weight. This is also a tried and true method in modern building construction and often required by code in areas that see a lot of shear stress whether from high winds or earthquakes.

posts.com:
>>2547858
Similar but better solution:
Cut a piece of thin plywood (1/4" is plenty) or Masonite that fits into and covers the open area without binding.
Glue/nail 3/4" W × 3/4"-1" H wooden strips around the perimiter to form a lip on the bottom.
Hold it up into place and screw it into the wall through the lip (make pilot holes so you dont crack the lip).
Now you have a removable inspection panel that is easier and cleaner than drywall even if you never need to take it off again.
If you want it fancy, you can take a router to the inside edge of the lip to make it look more like decorative molding and countersink/ fill the screw holes, and caulk the perimiter seam.
If one big panel is too unweildy to get in place, split it into two smaller ones.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Semi-professional here. I'm no chimney sweeper, but installing oil and gas fireing systems is part of my job. When we install open gas "furnaces", ovens or heating systems there is actually a formula and a bunch of rules of thumb with that you can calculate the need of air of an open fire regarding 2 points:
First one, "mixing of exhaust fumes with fresh air", according to the law, is of course the protection of health and life - ever heared of carbon monoxide poisoning?
Second one is providing that your fire has enough "fresh oxygen" for the combustion itself - just because you light something on fire it doesn't mean its burning properly. Ever saw a coal rolling diesel engine? Its because the oxygen-combustion mix isn't right.

Now, how a chimney works is actually more than just "hot smoke goes up" - there is thermodynamics and very complicated shit - since its only a small part of my job I don't know everything about it.

Long story short - forget the glass. Your fireplace burns oxygen and the exhaust fumes go up into the chinmey - as long as there is new oxygen and some pressure to keep the chinmey system working.

What you need is ventilation, and as you don't want to open your windows you have 2 options: Picture related in your doors, you can actually use a jigsaw and some screws to install them. Alternatively you can make a core-drilling in some wall, preferably in the room of your fireplace, and put some faceplate there.

But forget about the glass, first of all its extremely hard as non-craftsman to properly process the right glass so it doesn't shatter and secondly your fire isn't gonna work anymore (or burn very shitty) as it can't get anymore oxygen.
